cs113.calendar.guiview
Class CalendarArea

java.lang.Object
  java.awt.Component
      java.awt.Container
          javax.swing.JComponent
              javax.swing.JPanel
                  cs113.calendar.guiview.CalendarArea
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.awt.image.ImageObserver, java.awt.MenuContainer, java.io.Serializable, javax.accessibility.Accessible
public class CalendarArea
extends javax.swing.JPanel

This is the heart of the calendar. It tries to actually look like a calendar. It has a zoomy-navigation thing that some people find unpleasant but it allows you to un-scrunch appointments that are way close together in a day.

Author:
Owen Healy
See Also:
Serialized Form

selectionUpdateInProgress

private boolean selectionUpdateInProgress
Don't ask. Just don't ask. OK, since you asked, this says that we are right now changing which appointment is selected, which, because it make trigger new ItemEvents that are in response to something that the user did not do, we need to ignore, or we'll get into an infinite cycle of events.

Constructor Detail

CalendarArea

public CalendarArea(ViewState viewState,
                    Controller controller)
Create, layout, etc. Won't have any appointments in it at this point, but it should otherwise look OK. It will query the viewState to get the time it should be using. The ViewState better give it a valid time or it won't make something pretty.

Parameters:
viewState - Application's ViewState.
controller - Application's Controller.
Method Detail

setView

public void setView()
Read the current state from the ViewState and update the view accordingly. If it's a view we don't normally handle you shouldn't have called this method and we'll just pretend this little episode didn't happen.

Returns:

layoutArea

private void layoutArea()
Determine where to place the boundaries of the grid.

setupGrid

private void setupGrid()
This creates the DayCell objects and puts them in to the grid. It also creates the HourDivision objects for each row.

layoutGrid

private void layoutGrid()
This lays out the x's and the y's in the grid. It uses a weighted partition so that you can zoom in on a particular day.

weightedPartition

private static void weightedPartition(double[] weights,
                                      double start,
                                      double end,
                                      double[] partition)
Turns a vector of weights into a vector of boundaries.

Parameters:
weights - The weights.
start - The first boundary.
end - The last boundary.
partition - The vector to stick the partitions into.

boxupAppointments

private void boxupAppointments()
Make boxes for the appointments. Doesn't lay them out.

boxupAppointment

private void boxupAppointment(Appointment app)
Make a box for a particular appointment.

Parameters:
app - An appointment to make a box for.

layoutHourDivisions

private void layoutHourDivisions()
Layout the hours within each row of the grid. Gives more weight to hours that have stuff in them. Boxes must have been added for this to make sense.

layoutHourDivision

private void layoutHourDivision(int row)
Lays out the hours for one row of the grid.

Parameters:
row - A row in the grid.

checkColHours

private void checkColHours(int row,
                           int col,
                           boolean[] interesting)
Check to see whether any of the hours in the day row,col have stuff in them. If they do, they are "interesting".

Parameters:
row - A row in the grid.
col - A col in the grid.
interesting - A vector of hours. True if they're "interesting".
